An MDP \mathcal {M}=(\mathcal {S},\mathcal {A},H,P,r) is called a linear MDP if there exists two feature maps \phi :\mathcal {S}\times \mathcal {A}\rightarrow \mathbb {R}^{d}, \mu :\mathcal {S}\rightarrow \mathbb {R}^{d} and a vector \theta _{r}\in \mathbb {R}^{d}, such that
P(s^{\prime }|s,a)=\langle \phi (s,a),\mu (s^{\prime })\rangle ,\quad r(s,a)=\langle \phi (s,a),\theta _{r}\rangle
and \phi and \mu also satisfy the normalization conditions:
\begin {align*} &\forall (s,a),\ \lVert \phi (s,a) \rVert _{2} \leq 1,\ \lVert \theta _{r}\rVert _{2} \leq \sqrt {d} \\ &\forall g:\mathcal {S}\rightarrow \mathbb {R},\ \lVert g \rVert _{L_{\infty }}\leq 1\ \Rightarrow \left \lVert \int _{\mathcal {S}}\mu (s^{\prime })g(s^{\prime })ds^{\prime }\right \rVert _{2}\leq \sqrt {d} \end {align*}
